description: Developmental psychology essentials across lifespan: infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood. Covers cognitive, social, emotional, moral, and language development with applied, non-clinical framing.

theories.name: Piaget: Cognitive Development Stages
theories.oneLiner: Children’s thinking changes qualitatively through stages as they build mental models of the world.
coreMechanism: Schemas change via assimilation and accommodation.
Stage-like shifts: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, formal operational.
Limits depend on maturation + experience.
actionablePrinciples: Match explanations to the person’s cognitive level (concrete vs abstract).
Use examples and hands-on demonstrations before formal rules.
Check comprehension with ‘show me’ rather than ‘tell me’ when possible.

faceExamples.title: Explaining a complex idea to a child
faceExamples.scenario: User needs to explain a concept to a kid.
faceExamples.application: Use concrete analogies and visible steps; avoid heavy abstraction.

intentSignals: how to explain to a child

theories.name: Vygotsky: Zone of Proximal Development & Scaffolding
theories.oneLiner: Learning accelerates when support is calibrated to what someone can almost do independently.
coreMechanism: ZPD: gap between independent ability and guided ability.
Scaffolding: temporary supports removed over time.
Language and social interaction shape thought.
actionablePrinciples: Identify the ‘next doable step’ and scaffold just that.
Use prompts, hints, and partial solutions—then fade support.
Translate tasks into manageable subskills with feedback loops.

faceExamples.title: Teaching a new workflow
faceExamples.scenario: User is onboarding someone to a process.
faceExamples.application: Demonstrate, then guide, then hand off as competence grows.

theories.name: Erikson: Psychosocial Development
theories.oneLiner: Across life stages, people face identity and relationship tasks that shape well-being and behavior.
coreMechanism: Stage challenges (e.g., trust vs mistrust; identity vs role confusion).
Successful resolution supports resilience and future relationships.
Unresolved tension can reappear under stress.
actionablePrinciples: When conflict repeats, check the underlying stage-task (trust, autonomy, identity, intimacy).
Support identity coherence: values, roles, and goals alignment.
Separate the ‘problem’ from the ‘developmental task’ it threatens.

faceExamples.title: Identity friction in a pivot
faceExamples.scenario: User feels unsettled when changing direction.
faceExamples.application: Frame it as identity + role integration, not just logistics.

theories.name: Attachment Theory
theories.oneLiner: Early relationship patterns shape expectations of support, closeness, and safety—especially under stress.
coreMechanism: Attachment behaviors activate when threat or uncertainty rises.
Secure attachment supports exploration and emotion regulation.
Insecurity can increase avoidance, anxiety, or mixed signals.
actionablePrinciples: Under stress, increase predictability and reassurance through clear commitments.
Use repair language after conflict: name impact, take responsibility, propose a concrete change.
Don’t pathologize: treat patterns as adaptive responses to past conditions.

faceExamples.title: Conflict escalates under pressure
faceExamples.scenario: User sees relationship tension spike during deadlines.
faceExamples.application: Stabilize safety signals first; then discuss the issue.

intentSignals: why do I react like this

theories.name: Temperament & Goodness-of-Fit
theories.oneLiner: People differ in baseline reactivity and self-regulation; outcomes improve when environments fit temperament.
coreMechanism: Temperament includes reactivity, emotional intensity, and regulation capacity.
Goodness-of-fit: the same trait can thrive or struggle depending on context.
Misfit increases friction, not moral failure.
actionablePrinciples: Design environments around strengths (energy, sensitivity, routine need).
When friction repeats, adjust context before blaming character.
Use predictable routines for high-reactivity profiles.

faceExamples.title: High-intensity kid in chaotic routine
faceExamples.scenario: User reports frequent blow-ups in evenings.
faceExamples.application: Simplify transitions; increase predictability; reduce overstimulation.

intentSignals: why is this person like this
how do I handle this pattern

theories.name: Parenting Styles (Authoritative, Authoritarian, Permissive, Neglectful)
theories.oneLiner: Balanced warmth + structure (authoritative) tends to support competence and self-regulation.
coreMechanism: Warmth/Responsiveness and Control/Demandingness as core dimensions.
Authoritative combines high warmth + clear boundaries.
Inconsistent or harsh control can increase conflict or avoidance.
actionablePrinciples: Pair limits with empathy: ‘I get it’ + ‘here’s the boundary.’
Make consequences predictable and proportional.
Use ‘do this next’ instructions instead of only ‘don’t.’

theories.name: Theory of Mind
theories.oneLiner: Social understanding grows as people learn others have different beliefs, intentions, and perspectives.
coreMechanism: Perspective-taking improves with development and practice.
Misreads often come from assuming shared knowledge.
Stress narrows perspective-taking.
actionablePrinciples: When conflict arises, check assumptions: ‘What do they believe is happening?’
Use ‘steelman then respond’ in disagreements.
Make implicit context explicit in instructions and collaboration.

faceExamples.title: Team misunderstanding
faceExamples.application: Force shared mental model: definitions, goals, constraints.

theories.name: Executive Function Development
theories.oneLiner: Planning, inhibition, and working memory mature over time and are vulnerable under stress and sleep loss.
coreMechanism: Executive functions include inhibition, shifting, updating.
Prefrontal systems develop into early adulthood.
Stress, fatigue, and overload degrade EF performance.
actionablePrinciples: Use external scaffolds: checklists, timers, environmental design.
Reduce choices under high load; pre-decide defaults.
Treat EF failures as context failures first (sleep, stress, complexity).

faceExamples.title: Procrastination under pressure
faceExamples.application: Shrink task, reduce friction, commit to a 10-minute start.

theories.name: Adolescent Development: Reward Sensitivity & Risk
theories.oneLiner: During adolescence, reward systems can outpace control systems, increasing novelty seeking and sensitivity to peers.
coreMechanism: Heightened reward sensitivity and social salience.
Developing prefrontal control and long-term planning.
Peer context can amplify risk behavior.
actionablePrinciples: Reduce risk through context design (supervision, structure, alternatives).
Use collaborative rule-setting and clear rationale.
Avoid shame; focus on skill-building and decision environments.

faceExamples.title: Risky choices with friends
faceExamples.scenario: User worries about teen behavior in groups.
faceExamples.application: Plan safer defaults before the situation occurs.

intentSignals: how do I handle risky behavior

theories.name: Kohlberg: Moral Development
theories.oneLiner: Moral reasoning can progress from rule-avoidance to principled ethics, often shaped by discussion and perspective-taking.
coreMechanism: Preconventional: punishment/reward focus.
Conventional: social approval and law/order.
Postconventional: principles and rights.
actionablePrinciples: Frame dilemmas with reasons, not just rules.
Use guided discussion: ‘What values conflict here?’
Expect mixed-stage reasoning under stress.

faceExamples.title: Values conflict in a decision
faceExamples.scenario: User debates the ‘right’ choice under pressure.

theories.name: Language Development: Input, Interaction, and Practice
theories.oneLiner: Language grows through exposure, social interaction, and feedback; comprehension usually precedes production.
coreMechanism: Vocabulary growth via repeated meaningful exposure.
Social interaction strengthens learning and usage.
Feedback loops refine grammar and pragmatics.
actionablePrinciples: Increase high-quality input (reading, conversation) and repetition.
Use expansion: repeat the child’s sentence in correct, richer form.
Practice in real contexts, not only drills.

faceExamples.title: Supporting language growth
faceExamples.scenario: User wants to help a child communicate better.
faceExamples.application: More meaningful conversation, expansions, and routines.

theories.name: Aging: Selective Optimization with Compensation
theories.oneLiner: With aging, people adapt by focusing on key goals, optimizing strengths, and compensating for losses.
coreMechanism: Selection: prioritize what matters most.
Optimization: invest in chosen domains.
Compensation: tools/strategies to offset declines.
actionablePrinciples: Choose fewer high-impact goals; protect energy.
Use aids and routines to compensate (calendars, automation).
Design systems for consistency over intensity.

faceExamples.title: Sustaining output over time
faceExamples.scenario: User wants long-term productivity without burnout.
faceExamples.application: Fewer priorities + stronger supports + smart compensation.

intentSignals: how do I keep going long term

applicationRules.instruction: Use developmental concepts for education and practical framing; do not diagnose disorders or recommend clinical treatment.
When interpreting behavior, prefer context + developmental stage explanations before trait judgments.
When surfacing a theory, include at least one actionable principle and one clarifying question if uncertainty is high.
Avoid rigid milestone claims; acknowledge variability and emphasize supportive environments.

meta.intendedUse: Developmental reasoning support layer for Marion psychology domain; improves interpretation and response framing for age/stage-related queries.
